Hi Julie,

I am in Southern Jefferson County, Missouri. Where
are you located maybe we could get together for a
field trip or something. If we are even remotely close
geographically. I just pulled my kids out of public
school in January so we are very new to all of this.
Most of the time we just "wing it"

=====
Kim - Missouri MOM of Dylan(10) Jacob(10) Noah(20 mos)

messages.subject: Re: HELLO..mind if I come in?
messages.msgSnippet: It just takes some time to gain confidence..I agree with reading as many of the wonderful unschooing type books that you can get your hands on. The
messages.messageBody:
It just takes some time to gain confidence..I agree with reading as many of
the wonderful 'unschooing' type books that you can get your hands on.
"The Unschooling Handbook" by Mary Griffith is a one of my favorites. Also
on the unschoolers web page..read all of Sandra Dodd's essays...there is
tons of info and encouragement in the archives too!

My girls are 16, 10 and 5yrs old. We have been learning at home for 8yrs
now. Sometimes they are very busy with projects and ideas, and sometimes
they don't seem to be doing much of anything. They learn in spurts and
starts and stops..the same as I do.

Your girls are so young yet, just give them time to play, takes lots of
walks outdoors, trips to the library and bookstores, craft and hobby
shops..they will find things that they are interested in believe me!

As far as handling the relatives.. I just didn't share allot about our
personal lives with the ones that weren't supportive..at least not in the
beginning. Now they are all used to how we do things, and my kids are living
proof that 'unschooling' does work.

Julie in MO


>Hello
>I am in Rhode Island and have 2 terrific daughters (8 and 5) and we
>have been officially unschooling since Jan. Because I have some mild
>opposition and also some family members that ask "what did you DO in
>school today?" and because I haven't been doing this for long...I
>suppose I am not as secure as I'd like to be.
>My oldest lacks that persistent intrest driven motivation that I keep
>hearing about...she is kinda wishy-washy about her likes and has
>trouble making up her mind.
>I try to guide her now and then with suggestions and support but she
>is a tuff one --- We have tried classes that interest her, but she
>usually ends up not wanting to go any more.
>Sorry so long...anyone out there have a success story to a great kid
>like this ? Any suggestions ?
>Thanks !
